text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that? Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: the IV it’s about an hour. How’s that for fancy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s FDA approved for a cool, hundred thousand dollars so your insurance has to say yes number one, now don’t look at me with those eyes of yours. Secondly, we help you through that so that’s on us and if it’s not approved you won’t get it because people can’t, there’s no way we can afford that so we just would leave that but I might just start there to see if we can get the insurance to cover it. Most insurances will cover it, most insurances. So, that’s one. Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Now, the study that goes with that it isn’t whether you get the medicine or not, that’s a done deal, our study is to know what happens to your immune system so every time we see you we take ah blood from you so that we measure. Okay, what is this guy who’s supposed to fight this kind of infection. What’s his level? And what about this gal’s cell? What was she supposed to do? You know, it’s like who’s sleeping on the job Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: And it’s good for you and for me. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, we do have, uh, uh, the one drug called, Xtandi. We have two clinical trials, and those trials are both trying to make the drug work better by combining it with other, other drugs- Patient: Hum. Doctor: That in some ways compliment the hormone therapy. Uh, both of the two trials that we have, though, do require a biopsy, and I don’t know, I’ll have to go back and look to see if they’d allow a bone biopsy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The bone biopsy for you would be similar to any kind of biopsy. They have to numb up your skin, and put a needle, and take a piece of whatever they’re trying to take a piece of. For us, the bone biopsy, the yield is much lower, meaning they don’t always get actual tumor cells, because within the bone, it’s just they’re sort of taking a shot at, you know, what they think might be the tumor. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the, uh, the other trial we have is my, I talked before about this bone marrow transplant trial, which, um, is, you know, more kind of aggressive, uh, and kind of still in its early stages. So I can’t tell ya much about- we’ve treated two patients, and, uh, they both did really well with the bone marrow transplant. One guy has been pretty stable for, you know, going on two years, and one guy’s disease responded, and then it sort of progressed now, and he’s, he’s on chemotherapy.

text: Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose?

Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
